questions.question: Who made the world?
questions.answer: God made the world.

questions.question: Who is God?
questions.answer: God is the Creator of heaven and earth, and of all things.

questions.question: What is man?
questions.answer:
Man is a creature composed of body and soul, and made to the image
and likeness of God.

questions.question: Why did God make you?
questions.answer:
God made me to know Him, to love Him, and to serve Him in this world,
and to be happy with Him forever in the next.

questions.question: What must we do to save our souls?
How shall we know the things which we are to believe?
questions.answer:
We shall know the things which we are to believe from the Catholic
Church, through which God speaks to us.

questions.question: Where shall we find the chief truths which the Church teaches?
questions.answer:
We shall find the chief truths which the Church teaches in the
Apostles' Creed.

questions.question: Say the Apostles' Creed.
questions.answer:
I believe in God, the Father Almighty, Creator of heaven and earth;
and in Jesus Christ, His only Son, our Lord; who was conceived by the
Holy Ghost, born of the Virgin Mary, suffered under Pontius Pilate, was
crucified; died, and was buried. He descended into hell: the third day
He arose again from the dead: He ascended into heaven, and sitteth at
the right hand of God, the Father Almighty; from thence He shall come to
judge the living and the dead. I believe in the Holy Ghost, the Holy
Catholic Church, the communion of Saints, the forgiveness of sins, the
resurrection of the body, and the life everlasting. Amen.

questions.question: What is God?
questions.answer: God is a spirit infinitely perfect.

questions.question: Had God a beginning?
questions.answer: God had no beginning; He always was and He always will be.

questions.question: Where is God?
questions.answer: God is everywhere.

questions.question: If God is everywhere, why do we not see Him?
questions.answer:
We do not see God, because He is a pure spirit and cannot be seen
with bodily eyes.

questions.question: Does God see us?
questions.answer: God sees us and watches over us.

questions.question: Does God know all things?
questions.answer:
God knows all things, even our most secret thoughts, words, and
actions.

questions.question: Can God do all things?
questions.answer: God can do all things, and nothing is hard or impossible to Him.

questions.question: Is God just, holy, and merciful?
questions.answer: God is all just, all holy, all merciful, as He is infinitely perfect.

lessons.title: ON THE UNITY AND TRINITY OF GOD

questions.question: Is there but one God?
questions.answer: Yes; there is but one God.

questions.question: Why can there be but one God?
questions.answer:
There can be but one God, because God, being supreme and infinite,
cannot have an equal.

questions.question: How many Persons are there in God?
questions.answer:
In God there are three Divine Persons, really distinct, and equal in
all things--the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: Is the Father God?
questions.answer: The Father is God and the first Person of the Blessed Trinity.

questions.question: Is the Son God?
questions.answer: The Son is God and the second Person of the Blessed Trinity.

questions.question: Is the Holy Ghost God?
questions.answer: The Holy Ghost is God and the third Person of the Blessed Trinity.

questions.question: What is the Blessed Trinity?
questions.answer: The Blessed Trinity is one God in three Divine Persons.

questions.question: Are the three Divine Persons one and the same God?
questions.answer:
The three Divine Persons are one and the same God, having one and the
same Divine nature.

lessons.title: ON THE ANGELS AND OUR FIRST PARENTS

questions.question: Which are the chief creatures of God?
questions.answer: The chief creatures of God are men and angels.

questions.question: What are angels?
questions.answer: Angels are bodiless spirits created to adore and enjoy God in heaven.

questions.question: Who were the first man and woman?
questions.answer: The first man and woman were Adam and Eve.

questions.question:
Were Adam and Eve innocent and holy when they came from the hand
of God?
questions.answer:
Adam and Eve were innocent and holy when they came from the hand of
God.

questions.question: Did Adam and Eve remain faithful to God?
questions.answer:
Adam and Eve did not remain faithful to God; but broke His command by
eating the forbidden fruit.

questions.question: What befell Adam and Eve on account of their sin?
questions.answer:
Adam and Eve, on account of their sin, lost innocence and holiness,
and were doomed to misery and death.

questions.question:
What evil befell us through the disobedience of our first
parents?
questions.answer:
Through the disobedience of our first parents we all inherit their
sin and punishment, as we should have shared in their happiness if they
had remained faithful.

questions.question: What is the sin called which we inherit from our first parents?
questions.answer:
The sin which we inherit from our first parents is called original
sin.

questions.question: Was any one ever preserved from original sin?
questions.answer:
The Blessed Virgin Mary, through the merits of her Divine Son, was
preserved free from the guilt of original sin, and this privilege is
called her Immaculate Conception.

questions.question: Is original sin the only kind of sin?
questions.answer:
Original sin is not the only kind of sin; there is another kind of
sin, which we commit ourselves, called actual sin.

questions.question: What is actual sin?
questions.answer:
Actual sin is any wilful thought, word, deed or omission contrary to
the law of God.

questions.question: How many kinds of actual sin are there?
questions.answer: There are two kinds of actual sin--mortal and venial.

questions.question: What is mortal sin?
questions.answer: Mortal sin is a grievous offense against the law of God.

questions.question: What is venial sin?
questions.answer:
Venial sin is a slight offense against the law of God in matters of
less importance; or in matters of great importance it is an offense
committed without sufficient reflection or full consent of the will.

questions.question: Which are the chief sources of sin?
questions.answer:
The chief sources of sin are seven: Pride, Covetousness, Lust, Anger,
Gluttony, Envy, and Sloth; and they are commonly called capital sins.

questions.question: Did God abandon man after he fell into sin?
questions.answer:
God did not abandon man after he fell into sin, but promised him a
Redeemer, who was to satisfy for man's sin and reopen to him the gates
of heaven.

questions.question: Who is the Redeemer?
questions.answer: Our Blessed Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ is the Redeemer of mankind.

questions.question: What do you believe of Jesus Christ?
questions.answer:
I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God, the second Person of
the Blessed Trinity, true God and true man.

questions.question: What do you mean by the Incarnation?
questions.answer: By the Incarnation I mean that the Son of God was made man.

questions.question: How was the Son of God made man?
questions.answer:
The Son of God was conceived and made man by the power of the Holy
Ghost, in the womb of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

questions.question: On what day was the Son of God conceived and made man?
questions.answer:
The Son of God was conceived and made man on Annunciation day--the
day on which the Angel Gabriel announced to the Blessed Virgin Mary that
she was to be the Mother of God.

questions.question: On what day was Christ born?
questions.answer:
Christ was born on Christmas day in a stable at Bethlehem, over
nineteen hundred years ago.

lessons.title: ON OUR LORD'S PASSION, DEATH, RESURRECTION, AND ASCENSION

questions.question: What did Jesus Christ suffer?
questions.answer:
Jesus Christ suffered a bloody sweat, a cruel scourging, was crowned
with thorns, and was crucified.

questions.question: On what day did Christ die?
questions.answer: Christ died on Good Friday.

questions.question: Why did Christ suffer and die?
questions.answer: Christ suffered and died for our sins.

questions.question: On what day did Christ rise from the dead?
questions.answer:
Christ rose from the dead, glorious and immortal, on Easter Sunday,
the third day after His death.

questions.question: After Christ had remained forty days on earth, whither did He go?
questions.answer:
After forty days Christ ascended into heaven, and the day on which He
ascended into heaven is called Ascension day.

lessons.title: ON THE HOLY GHOST AND HIS DESCENT UPON THE APOSTLES

questions.question: Who is the Holy Ghost?
questions.answer: The Holy Ghost is the third Person of the Blessed Trinity.

questions.question: On what day did the Holy Ghost come down upon the Apostles?
questions.answer:
The Holy Ghost came down upon the Apostles ten days after the
Ascension of our Lord; and the day on which He came down upon the
Apostles is called Whitsunday, or Pentecost.

questions.question: Who sent the Holy Ghost upon the Apostles?
questions.answer: Our Lord Jesus Christ sent the Holy Ghost upon the Apostles.

questions.question: Why did Christ send the Holy Ghost?
questions.answer:
Christ sent the Holy Ghost to sanctify His Church, to enlighten and
strengthen the Apostles, and to enable them to preach the Gospel.

lessons.title: ON THE EFFECTS OF THE REDEMPTION

questions.question: Which are the chief effects of the Redemption?
questions.answer:
The chief effects of the Redemption are two: The satisfaction of
God's justice by Christ's sufferings and death, and the gaining of grace
for men.

questions.question: What do you mean by grace?
questions.answer:
By grace I mean a supernatural gift of God bestowed on us, through
the merits of Jesus Christ, for our salvation.

questions.question: How many kinds of grace are there?
questions.answer: There are two kinds of grace, sanctifying grace and actual grace.

questions.question: What is sanctifying grace?
questions.answer:
Sanctifying grace is that grace which makes the soul holy and
pleasing to God.

questions.question: What is actual grace?
questions.answer:
Actual grace is that help of God which enlightens our mind and moves
our will to shun evil and do good.

{T.N.: The above question is out of numerical order in the printed
source of Baltimore Catechism No. 1.}

questions.question: What is Faith?
questions.answer:
Faith is a Divine virtue by which we firmly believe the truths which
God has revealed.

questions.question: What is Hope?
questions.answer:
Hope is a Divine virtue by which we firmly trust that God will give
us eternal life and the means to obtain it.

questions.question: What is Charity?
questions.answer:
Charity is a Divine virtue by which we love God above all things for
His own sake, and our neighbor as ourselves for the love of God.

questions.question:
Which are the means instituted by our Lord to enable men at all
times to share in the fruits of the Redemption?
questions.answer:
The means instituted by our Lord to enable men at all times to share
in the fruits of His Redemption are the Church and the Sacraments.

questions.question: What is the Church?
questions.answer:
The Church is the congregation of all those who profess the faith of
Christ, partake of the same Sacraments, and are governed by their lawful
pastors under one visible Head.

questions.question: Who is the invisible Head of the Church?
questions.answer: Jesus Christ is the invisible Head of the Church.

questions.question: Who is the visible Head of the Church?
questions.answer:
Our Holy Father the Pope, the Bishop of Rome, is the Vicar of Christ
on earth, and the visible Head of the Church.

questions.question: Has the Church any marks by which it may be known?
questions.answer:
The Church has four marks by which it may be known: it is One; it is
Holy; it is Catholic; it is Apostolic.

questions.question: In which Church are these marks found?
questions.answer: These marks are found in the Holy Roman Catholic Church alone.

questions.question: What is a Sacrament?
questions.answer: A Sacrament is an outward sign instituted by Christ to give grace.

questions.question: How many Sacraments are there?
questions.answer:
There are seven Sacraments: Baptism, Confirmation, Holy Eucharist,
Penance, Extreme Unction, Holy Orders, and Matrimony.

questions.question: Whence have the Sacraments the power of giving grace?
questions.answer:
The Sacraments have the power of giving grace from the merits of
Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Do the Sacraments always give grace?
questions.answer:
The Sacraments always give grace, if we receive them with the right
dispositions.

questions.question: Can we receive the Sacraments more than once?
questions.answer:
We can receive the Sacraments more than once, except Baptism,
Confirmation, and Holy Orders.

questions.question: What is Baptism?
questions.answer:
Baptism is a Sacrament which cleanses us from original sin, makes us
Christians, children of God, and heirs of heaven.

questions.question: Are actual sins ever remitted by Baptism?
questions.answer:
Actual sins and all the punishment due to them are remitted by
Baptism, if the person baptized be guilty of any, and is rightly
disposed.

questions.question: Is Baptism necessary to salvation?
questions.answer:
Baptism is necessary to salvation, because without it we cannot enter
into the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: Who can administer Baptism?
questions.answer:
The priest is the ordinary minister of Baptism; but in case of
necessity any one who has the use of reason may baptize.

questions.question: How is Baptism given?
questions.answer:
Whoever baptizes should pour water on the head of the person to be
baptized, and say, while pouring the water: I baptize thee in the name
of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: What is Confirmation?
questions.answer:
Confirmation is a Sacrament through which we receive the Holy Ghost
to make us strong and perfect Christians and soldiers of Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Who administers Confirmation?
questions.answer: The bishop is the ordinary minister of Confirmation.

questions.question: How does the bishop give Confirmation?
questions.answer:
The bishop extends his hands over those who are to be confirmed,
prays that they may receive the Holy Ghost, and anoints the forehead of
each with holy chrism in the form of a cross.

questions.question: What does the bishop say in anointing the person he confirms?
questions.answer:
In anointing the person he confirms the bishop says: I sign thee with
the sign of the cross, and I confirm thee with the chrism of salvation,
in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

questions.question:
To receive Confirmation worthily is it necessary to be in the
state of grace?
questions.answer:
To receive Confirmation worthily it is necessary to be in the state
of grace.

questions.question: What is a state of grace?
questions.answer:
A state of grace is freedom from mortal sin.

{T.N.: The above question is numbered 174 in the printed source, but a
different question is given in its place in Baltimore Catechism Nos. 2
and 4, where the topic is covered in Q. 55 and elsewhere.}

questions.question: Is it a sin to neglect Confirmation?
questions.answer:
It is a sin to neglect Confirmation, especially in these evil days
when faith and morals are exposed to so many and such violent
temptations.

questions.question: What is the Sacrament of Penance?
questions.answer:
Penance is a Sacrament in which the sins committed after Baptism are
forgiven.

questions.question: What must we do to receive the Sacrament of Penance worthily?
questions.answer: To receive the Sacrament of Penance worthily we must do five things:

list.text: We must examine our conscience.
We must have sorrow for our sins.
We must make a firm resolution never more to offend God.
We must confess our sins to the priest.
We must accept the penance which the priest gives us.

questions.question: What is the examination of conscience?
questions.answer:
The examination of conscience is an earnest effort to recall to mind
all the sins we have committed since our last worthy confession.

questions.question: What is contrition, or sorrow for sin?
questions.answer:
Contrition, or sorrow for sin, is a hatred of sin and a true grief of
the soul for having offended God, with a firm purpose of sinning no
more.

questions.question: Why should we be sorry for our sins?
questions.answer:
We should be sorry for our sins, because sin is the greatest of evils
and an offense against God our Creator, Preserver, and Redeemer, and
because mortal sin shuts us out of heaven and condemns us to the eternal
pains of hell.

questions.question: What do you mean by a firm purpose of sinning no more?
questions.answer:
By a firm purpose of sinning no more I mean a fixed resolve not only
to avoid all mortal sin, but also its near occasions.

questions.question: What do you mean by the near occasions of sin?
questions.answer:
By the near occasions of sin I mean all the persons, places, and
things that may easily lead us into sin.

questions.question: What is Confession?
questions.answer:
Confession is the telling of our sins to a duly authorized priest,
for the purpose of obtaining forgiveness.

questions.question: What sins are we bound to confess?
questions.answer:
We are bound to confess all our mortal sins, but it is well also to
confess our venial sins.

questions.question: What should we do if we cannot remember the number of our sins?
questions.answer:
If we cannot remember the number of our sins, we should tell the
number as nearly as possible.

questions.question:
Is it a grievous offense wilfully to conceal a mortal sin in
Confession?
questions.answer:
It is a grievous offense wilfully to conceal a mortal sin in
Confession, because we thereby tell a lie to the Holy Ghost, and make
our Confession worthless.

questions.question:
What must he do who has wilfully concealed a mortal sin in
Confession?
questions.answer:
He who has wilfully concealed a mortal sin in Confession must not
only confess it, but must also repeat all the sins he has committed
since his last worthy Confession.

questions.question: Why does the priest give us a penance after Confession?
questions.answer:
The priest gives us a penance after Confession that we may satisfy
God for the temporal punishment due to our sins.

questions.question: What is an Indulgence?
questions.answer:
An Indulgence is the remission in whole or in part of the temporal
punishment due to sin.

questions.question: How many kinds of Indulgences are there?
questions.answer: There are two kinds of Indulgences--Plenary and Partial.

questions.question: What is a Plenary Indulgence?
questions.answer:
A Plenary Indulgence is the full remission of the temporal punishment
due to sin.

questions.question: What is a Partial Indulgence?
questions.answer:
A Partial Indulgence is the remission of a part of the temporal
punishment due to sin.

questions.question: What must we do to gain an Indulgence?
questions.answer:
To gain an Indulgence we must be in the state of grace and perform
the works enjoined.

questions.question: What is the Holy Eucharist?
questions.answer:
The Holy Eucharist is the Sacrament which contains the body and
blood, soul and divinity, of our Lord Jesus Christ under the appearances
of bread and wine.

questions.question: What do you mean by the appearances of bread and wine?
questions.answer:
By the appearances of bread and wine I mean the figure, the color,
the taste, and whatever appears to the senses.

questions.question:
When did Christ give His priests the power to change bread and
wine into His body and blood?
questions.answer:
Christ gave His priests the power to change bread and wine into His
body and blood when He said to the Apostles, Do this for a commemoration
of Me.

questions.question:
How do the priests exercise this power of changing bread and
wine into the body and blood of Christ?
questions.answer:
The priests exercise this power of changing bread and wine into the
body and blood of Christ through the words of consecration in the Mass,
which are the words of Christ: This is My body; this is My blood.

lessons.title: ON THE ENDS FOR WHICH THE HOLY EUCHARIST WAS INSTITUTED

questions.question: Why did Christ institute the Holy Eucharist?
questions.answer: Christ instituted the Holy Eucharist--

list.text:
To unite us to Himself and to nourish our soul with His body and
   blood.
To increase sanctifying grace and all virtues in our soul.
To lessen our evil inclinations.
To be a pledge of everlasting life.
To fit our bodies for a glorious resurrection.
To continue the sacrifice of the cross in His Church.

questions.question: What is Holy Communion?
questions.answer: Holy Communion is the receiving of the body and blood of Christ.

questions.question: What is necessary to make a good Communion?
questions.answer:
To make a good Communion it is necessary to be in the state of
grace and to be fasting for one hour from food and all drinks, except
water.

[This answer has been changed in the 1977 edition to bring it up to
date with the current rules.]

questions.question:
Does he who receives Communion in mortal sin receive the body
and blood of Christ?
questions.answer:
He who receives Communion in mortal sin receives the body and blood
of Christ, but does not receive His grace, and he commits a great
sacrilege.

lessons.title: ON THE SACRIFICE OF THE MASS

questions.question:
When are the bread and wine changed into the body and blood of
Christ?
questions.answer:
The bread and wine are changed into the body and blood of Christ at
the consecration in the Mass.

questions.question: What is the Mass?
questions.answer: The Mass is the unbloody sacrifice of the body and blood of Christ.

questions.question: Is the Mass the same sacrifice as that of the cross?
questions.answer: The Mass is the same sacrifice as that of the cross.

questions.question: How should we assist at Mass?
questions.answer:
We should assist at Mass with great interior recollection and piety,
and with every outward mark of respect and devotion.

lessons.title: ON EXTREME UNCTION AND HOLY ORDERS

questions.question: What is the Sacrament of Extreme Unction?
questions.answer:
Extreme Unction is the Sacrament which, through the anointing and
prayer of the priest, gives health and strength to the soul, and
sometimes to the body, when we are in danger of death from sickness.

questions.question: Which are the effects of the Sacrament of Extreme Unction?
questions.answer:
The effects of Extreme Unction are: 1st, to comfort us in the pains
of sickness and to strengthen us against temptation; 2d, to remit venial
sins and to cleanse our soul from the remains of sin; 3d, to restore us
to health, when God sees fit.

questions.question: What is the Sacrament of Holy Orders?
questions.answer:
Holy Orders is a Sacrament by which bishops, priests, and other
ministers of the Church are ordained and receive the power and grace to
perform their sacred duties.

questions.question: What is the Sacrament of Matrimony?
questions.answer:
The Sacrament of Matrimony is the Sacrament which unites a Christian
man and woman in lawful marriage.

questions.question: Which are the effects of the Sacrament of Matrimony?
questions.answer:
The effects of the Sacrament of Matrimony are: 1st, to sanctify the
love of husband and wife; 2d, to give them grace to bear with each
other's weaknesses; 3d, to enable them to bring up their children in the
fear and love of God.

questions.question:
To receive the Sacrament of matrimony worthily is it necessary
to be in the state of grace?
questions.answer:
To receive the Sacrament of Matrimony worthily it is necessary to be
in the state of grace, and it is necessary also to comply with the laws
of the Church.

questions.question: What is a sacramental?
questions.answer:
A sacramental is anything set apart or blessed by the Church to
excite good thoughts and to increase devotion, and through these
movements of the heart to remit venial sin.

questions.question: Which is the chief sacramental used in the Church?
questions.answer: The chief sacramental used in the Church is the sign of the cross.

questions.question: How do we make the sign of the cross?
questions.answer:
We make the sign of the cross by putting the right hand to the
forehead, then on the breast, and then to the left and right shoulders,
saying, In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy
Ghost. Amen.

questions.question: Why do we make the sign of the cross?
questions.answer:
We make the sign of the cross to show that we are Christians and to
profess our belief in the chief mysteries of our religion.

questions.question: What other sacramental is in very frequent use?
questions.answer: Another sacramental in very frequent use is holy water.

questions.question: What is holy water?
questions.answer:
Holy water is water blessed by the priest with solemn prayer to beg
God's blessing on those who use it, and protection from the powers of
darkness.

questions.question:
Are there other sacramentals besides the sign of the cross and
holy water?
questions.answer:
Besides the sign of the cross and holy water there are many other
sacramentals, such as blessed candles, ashes, palms, crucifixes, images
of the Blessed Virgin and of the saints, rosaries and scapulars.

questions.question:
Is there any other means of obtaining God's grace than the
Sacraments?
questions.answer: There is another means of obtaining God's grace, and it is prayer.

questions.question: What is prayer?
questions.answer:
Prayer is the lifting up of our minds and hearts to God to adore Him,
to thank Him for His benefits, to ask His forgiveness, and to beg of Him
all the graces we need, whether for soul or body.

questions.question: Is prayer necessary to salvation?
questions.answer:
Prayer is necessary to salvation, and without it no one having the
use of reason can be saved.

questions.question: At what particular times should we pray?
questions.answer:
We should pray particularly on Sundays and holydays, every morning
and night, in all dangers, temptations, and afflictions.

questions.question: Which are the prayers most recommended to us?
questions.answer:
The prayers most recommended to us are the Lord's Prayer, the Hail
Mary, the Apostles' Creed, the Confiteor, and the Acts of Faith, Hope,
Love and Contrition.

questions.question: Are prayers said with distractions of any avail?
questions.answer: Prayers said with wilful distractions are of no avail.

questions.question: Is it enough to belong to God's Church in order to be saved?
questions.answer:
It is not enough to belong to the Church in order to be saved, but we
must also keep the Commandments of God and of the Church.

questions.question: Which are the Commandments of God?
questions.answer: The Commandments of God are these ten:

list.text: I am the Lord thy God. Thou shalt not have strange gods before Me.
Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain.
Remember thou keep holy the Sabbath day.
Honor thy father and thy mother.
Thou shalt not kill.
Thou shalt not commit adultery.
Thou shalt not steal.
Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbor.
Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's wife.
Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's goods.

questions.question: What is the first Commandment?
questions.answer:
The first Commandment is: I am the Lord thy God: thou shalt not have
strange gods before Me.

questions.question: How do we adore God?
questions.answer: We adore God by faith, hope, and love, by prayer and sacrifice.

questions.question: How may the first Commandment be broken?
questions.answer:
The first Commandment may be broken by giving to a creature the honor
which belongs to God alone; by false worship; and by attributing to a
creature a perfection which belongs to God alone.

questions.question:
Are sins against faith, hope, and charity also sins against the
first Commandment?
questions.answer:
Sins against faith, hope, and charity are also sins against the first
Commandment.

questions.question: How does a person sin against faith?
questions.answer:
A person sins against faith: 1st, by not trying to know what God has
taught; 2d, by refusing to believe all that God has taught; 3d, by
neglecting to profess his belief in what God has taught.

questions.question: Are we obliged to make open profession of our faith?
questions.answer:
We are obliged to make open profession of our faith as often as God's
honor, our neighbor's spiritual good, or our own requires it.

questions.question: Which are the sins against hope?
questions.answer: The sins against hope are presumption and despair.

questions.question: What is presumption?
questions.answer:
Presumption is a rash expectation of salvation without making proper
use of the necessary means to obtain it.

questions.question: What is despair?
questions.answer: Despair is the loss of hope in God's mercy.

lessons.title: THE FIRST COMMANDMENT--ON THE HONOR AND INVOCATION OF SAINTS

questions.question: Does the first Commandment forbid the honoring of the saints?
questions.answer:
The first Commandment does not forbid the honoring of the saints, but
rather approves of it, because by honoring the saints, who are the
chosen friends of God, we honor God Himself.

questions.question: Does the first Commandment forbid us to pray to the saints?
questions.answer: The first Commandment does not forbid us to pray to the saints.

questions.question: What do we mean by praying to the saints?
questions.answer:
By praying to the saints we mean the asking of their help and
prayers.

questions.question: Does the first Commandment forbid us to honor relics?
questions.answer:
The first Commandment does not forbid us to honor relics, because
relics are the bodies of the saints or objects directly connected with
them or with our Lord.

questions.question: Does the first Commandment forbid the making of images?
questions.answer:
The first Commandment does forbid the making of images if they are
made to be adored as gods, but it does not forbid the making of them to
put us in mind of Jesus Christ, His Blessed Mother, and the saints.

questions.question:
Is it right to show respect to the pictures and images of Christ
and His saints?
questions.answer:
It is right to show respect to the pictures and images of Christ and
His saints, because they are the representations and memorials of them.

questions.question:
Is it allowed to pray to the crucifix or to the images and
relics of the saints?
questions.answer:
It is not allowed to pray to the crucifix or images and relics of the
saints, for they have no life, nor power to help us, nor sense to hear
us.

questions.question:
Why do we pray before the crucifix and the images and relics of
the saints?
questions.answer:
We pray before the crucifix and images and relics of the saints
because they enliven our devotion by exciting pious affections and
desires, and by reminding us of Christ and of the saints, that we may
imitate their virtues.

lessons.title: FROM THE SECOND TO THE FOURTH COMMANDMENT

questions.question: What is the second Commandment?
questions.answer:
The second Commandment is: Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord
thy God in vain.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the second Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the second Commandment to speak with reverence of
God and of the saints, and of all holy things, and to keep our lawful
oaths and vows.

questions.question: What is an oath?
questions.answer: An oath is the calling upon God to witness the truth of what we say.

questions.question: What is a vow?
questions.answer:
A vow is a deliberate promise made to God to do something that is
pleasing to Him.

questions.question: Is it a sin not to fulfill our vows?
questions.answer:
Not to fulfill our vows is a sin, mortal or venial, according to the
nature of the vow and the intention we had in making it.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the second Commandment?
questions.answer:
The second Commandment forbids all false, rash, unjust, and
unnecessary oaths, blasphemy, cursing, and profane words.

questions.question: What is the third Commandment?
questions.answer: The third Commandment is: Remember thou keep holy the Sabbath day.

questions.question: How are we to worship God on Sundays and holydays of obligation?
questions.answer:
We are to worship God on Sundays and holydays of obligation by
hearing Mass, by prayer, and by other good works.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the third Commandment?
questions.answer:
The third Commandment forbids all unnecessary servile work and
whatever else may hinder the due observance of the Lord's day.

questions.question: What are servile works?
questions.answer:
Servile works are those which require labor rather of body than of
mind.

questions.question: Are servile works on Sunday ever lawful?
questions.answer:
Servile works are lawful on Sunday when the honor of God, the good of
our neighbor, or necessity requires them.

lessons.title: FROM THE FOURTH TO THE SEVENTH COMMANDMENT

questions.question: What is the fourth Commandment?
questions.answer: The fourth Commandment is: Honor thy father and thy mother.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the fourth Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the fourth Commandment to honor, love, and obey
our parents in all that is not sin.

questions.question: Are we bound to honor and obey others than our parents?
questions.answer:
We are also bound to honor and obey our bishops, pastors,
magistrates, teachers, and other lawful superiors.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the fourth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The fourth Commandment forbids all disobedience, contempt, and
stubbornness towards our parents or lawful superiors.

questions.question: What is the fifth Commandment?
questions.answer: The fifth Commandment is: Thou shalt not kill.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the fifth Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the fifth Commandment to live in peace and union
with our neighbor, to respect his rights, to seek his spiritual and
bodily welfare, and to take proper care of our own life and health.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the fifth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The fifth Commandment forbids all wilful murder, fighting, anger,
hatred, revenge, and bad example.

questions.question: What is the sixth Commandment?
questions.answer: The sixth Commandment is: Thou shalt not commit adultery.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the sixth Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the sixth Commandment to be pure in thought and
modest in all our looks, words, and actions.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the sixth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The sixth commandment forbids all unchaste freedom with another's
wife or husband; also all immodesty with ourselves or others in looks,
dress, words, or actions.

questions.question:
Does the sixth Commandment forbid the reading of bad and
immodest books and newspapers?
questions.answer:
The sixth Commandment does forbid the reading of bad and immodest
books and newspapers.

lessons.title: FROM THE SEVENTH TO THE END OF THE TENTH COMMANDMENT

questions.question: What is the seventh Commandment?
questions.answer: The seventh Commandment is: Thou shalt not steal.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the seventh Commandment?
questions.answer:
By the seventh Commandment we are commanded to give to all men what
belongs to them and to respect their property.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the seventh Commandment?
questions.answer:
The seventh Commandment forbids all unjust taking or keeping what
belongs to another.

questions.question: Are we bound to restore ill-gotten goods?
questions.answer:
We are bound to restore ill-gotten goods, or the value of them, as
far as we are able; otherwise we cannot be forgiven.

questions.question: Are we obliged to repair the damage we have unjustly caused?
questions.answer: We are bound to repair the damage we have unjustly caused.

questions.question: What is the eighth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The eighth Commandment is: Thou shalt not bear false witness against
thy neighbor.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the eighth Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the eighth Commandment to speak the truth in all
things, and to be careful of the honor and reputation of every one.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the eighth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The eighth Commandment forbids all rash judgments, backbiting,
slanders, and lies.

questions.question: What is the ninth Commandment?
questions.answer: The ninth Commandment is: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's wife.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the ninth Commandment?
questions.answer:
We are commanded by the ninth Commandment to keep ourselves pure in
thought and desire.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the ninth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The ninth Commandment forbids unchaste thoughts, desires of another's
wife or husband, and all other unlawful impure thoughts and desires.

questions.question: What is the tenth Commandment?
questions.answer: The tenth Commandment is: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's goods.

questions.question: What are we commanded by the tenth Commandment?
questions.answer:
By the tenth Commandment we are commanded to be content with what we
have, and to rejoice in our neighbor's welfare.

questions.question: What is forbidden by the tenth Commandment?
questions.answer:
The tenth Commandment forbids all desires to take or keep wrongfully
what belongs to another.

lessons.title: ON THE FIRST AND SECOND COMMANDMENTS OF THE CHURCH

questions.question: Which are the chief commandments of the Church?
questions.answer: The chief commandments of the Church are six:

list.text: To hear Mass on Sundays and holydays of obligation.
To fast and abstain on the days appointed.
To confess at least once a year.
To receive the Holy Eucharist during the Easter time.
To contribute to the support of our pastors.

Not to marry persons who are not Catholics, or who are related to us
   within the third degree of kindred, nor privately without witnesses,
   nor to solemnize marriage at forbidden times.

questions.question:
Is it a mortal sin not to hear Mass on a Sunday or a holyday of
obligation?
questions.answer:
It is a mortal sin not to hear Mass on a Sunday or a holyday of
obligation unless we are excused for a serious reason. They also commit
a mortal sin who, having others under their charge, hinder them from
hearing Mass, without a sufficient reason.

questions.question: What do you mean by fast-days?
questions.answer: By fast-days I mean days on which we are allowed but one full meal.

questions.question: What do you mean by days of abstinence?
questions.answer:
By days of abstinence, I mean days on which we are forbidden to eat
flesh-meat, but are allowed the usual number of meals.

questions.question: Why does the Church command us to fast and abstain?
questions.answer:
The Church commands us to fast and abstain in order that we may
mortify our passions and satisfy for our sins.

lessons.title: ON THE THIRD, FOURTH, FIFTH AND SIXTH COMMANDMENTS OF THE CHURCH

questions.question: What is meant by the command of confessing at least once a year?
questions.answer:
By the command of confessing at least once a year is meant that we
are obliged, under pain of mortal sin, to go to Confession within the
year.

questions.question:
What sin does he commit who neglects to receive Communion during
the Easter time?
questions.answer:
He who neglects to receive Communion during the Easter time commits a
mortal sin.

questions.question: What is the Easter time?
questions.answer:
The Easter time is, in this country, the time between the first
Sunday of Lent and Trinity Sunday.

questions.question: Are we obliged to contribute to the support of our pastors?
questions.answer:
We are obliged to contribute to the support of our pastors, and to
bear our share in the expenses of the Church and school.

lessons.title: ON THE LAST JUDGMENT AND THE RESURRECTION, HELL, PURGATORY, AND HEAVEN

questions.question: When will Christ judge us?
questions.answer:
Christ will judge us immediately after our death, and on the last
day.

questions.question:
What is the judgment called which we have to undergo immediately
after death?
questions.answer:
The judgment we have to undergo immediately after death is called the
Particular Judgment.

questions.question:
What is the judgment called which all men have to undergo on the
last day?
questions.answer:
The judgment which all men have to undergo on the last day is called
the General Judgment.

questions.question:
What are the rewards or punishments appointed for men's souls
after the Particular Judgment?
questions.answer:
The rewards or punishments appointed for men's souls after the
Particular Judgment are Heaven, Purgatory, and Hell.

questions.question: What is Hell?
questions.answer:
Hell is a state to which the wicked are condemned, and in which they
are deprived of the sight of God for all eternity, and are in dreadful
torments.

questions.question: What is Purgatory?
questions.answer:
Purgatory is a state in which those suffer for a time who die guilty
of venial sins, or without having satisfied for the punishment due to
their sins.

questions.question: Will our bodies share in the reward or punishment of our souls?
questions.answer:
Our bodies will share in the reward or punishment of our souls,
because through the resurrection they will again be united to them.

questions.question: What is Heaven?
questions.answer:
Heaven is the state of everlasting life in which we see God face to
face, are made like unto Him in glory, and enjoy eternal happiness.
